lines.text: They were scary, your letters.
They were scary cus I was scared.
What was that?
I said the blessing.
I didn't hear anything.
I wasn't talking to you.
I'm not having dinner
And why not?
I had a big breakfast.
Jeremy, I'm not joking around out here!
I'm not laughin' around in here!
Look if you're going to talk to me about car-wrecks you can stop right now!
What? What are you talking about?
You told me that more people die in car-wrecks each year than died in Vietnam.
Well, I may have said that...
Not 'may have', did!
I wasn't screaming. I was using my loud voice.

You know how in horror movies the door is swinging back and forth from one hinge in front of a dark room, and some stupid moron is walking up to it, just gonna go in, and you think to yourself, 'Why is she doing that? Why is she going in there? What could possible make her go into that room? Doesn't she know better?'
Yeah.

[looks over at her house]
Don't let me go in there, please.
You know, I'm not gonna be mad at you, because I know you have personal problems.
What are they? What are these personal problems that I have?
I don't know the medical term, but I suppose you could describe it as being a terminal jerk.
[repeated line]
Did I ever tell you I was friends with a famous cowboy?
Stay away from my door.
It is only your door on the inside. It's anyone's door out here, and I'll stand by it as long as I want to, and you just try and stop me.
Well, unless we're going to have a nuclear attack of some kind, it's hard to imagine what else could go wrong.
I wish they could would make Thanksgiving on a Sunday. Then everyone could go to a service before they eat with their families. It'd be more religious, like it was with the Pilgrims.
What about the Indians?
Oh, Jeremy, there were no Indians at the first Thanksgiving.
That's why they have it. The Indians saved the Pilgrims from starvin' to death, so the Pilgrims invited the Indians to share their first harvest feast.
Well, I'm sure the Indians were all Christians by then.
Oh no, they weren't.
Look, it's not that I'm asking for the car...
Hm?
But you know Jesus didn't have a job.
That's right. He didn't have a car either, and he walked everywhere.
Okay, I know you don't want to hear this right now. And I know you think I'm a complete idiot, and I know that the last you want to do right now is have a conversation with me.
Knowledge is power.
D'you ship to Gnome, Alaska?
Look, I know you had a rough time over there.
'Over there'! You can't even say it.
What?
Vietnam
Seen all your stuff downstairs.
I want Karen to take me to the bus station.
Alright, fine.
[pulls money out of his pocket]
I got twenty-one hundred dollars here for you; it's all the cash I had at the office. It's not a fortune, but it'll get you where you want to go, and help you get started if you're careful with it.

[pauses]
And look, don't think that I'm kicking you out of the house, see. I think you should leave for for your own good, I think it's the right thing to do, and it's my responsibility as a father. Once you're away from here, and had time to think about, I think you'll agree.
I don't want it.
Well I want you to have it.
No you don't. You want me to take it, so you won't feel guilty, so you won't feel responsible.

[sighs]
It's funny how I can be so wrong. I honestly thought you were gonna say 'thank you'.
Thank you? That's what you thought I'd say? No. You just want everyone to think you did the right thing.
I'm not doing this on what anybody might think.
[puts the money down]
I'll have Karen drive you wherever you want to go.
[starts to close the door]
I hope you'll think better of me someday.

You know what? I'm sorry I prayed for you. I am! I never thought it'd be possible to be sorry for a thing like that! But I apologize to myself for all the times I got down on my knees and begged to God to bring you home safe!
Such a self-righteous little BITCH.
I am not taking this from you. You are NOTHING. You are a freak, an absolute zero, and you're not my brother anymore!
Two hundred and ninety nine.
What?

Two hundred and ninety nine, I said, don't tell me you don't know what that means David. I think your old man knows what it means don't you Howe? That's your goddamn birthday David. For when they pulled the numbers out for the draft card lottery. Two ninety-nine, that's the number that saved your ass from having to go and fight in Vietnam! Would you like to know what Jeremy's number was? It was eight, eight, EIGHT!
[throws cloth at David]
Don't you ever tell me what to say or what I can't say in my own house, or I'll take this goddamn turkey and shove it down your throat!
I was taught to honor your father and mother. That's what I've tried to teach... I guess I'm not good enough to deserve that kind of respect!
Of course you are.
[Karen preheats the oven and comes back to the table]
[about Jeremy]
I just don't understand what went wrong. His whole life he was so grown-up, so polite.
War changes people.
War doesn't make you rude to your parents!
Jeremy is this class a part of your major?
I don't have a major.
This is my house! I make the goddamn rules here!
You know Jeremy was screaming in his sleep again.
Yeah I know.
I think that's what's been bothering Mother.

[Jeremy is sitting outside on the porch]
You know it could be that he's waiting for someone to talk to him.
Maybe... but it's not us.

[from inside his room]
Fuck off.

[speechless at first]
What did you say?
I said fuck off, go fuck yourself!

[furious]
I'm gonna beat the shit outta you!
[pounds on door]

[on their mother]
She's gonna have a nervous breakdown.
I know she wants one. I know she ain't gonna be happy until she has one.
This is MY house!
This is your house? You know what, you can HAVE IT! What does that mean, this is my house? What does that MEAN?
[runs upstairs]

[the phone is ringing]
Tell whoever it is I died.

[it is late at night, and Jeremy has caught his father sneaking peanut brittle]
What is that, peanut brittle?
Yeah, your mother made some tonight for Thanksgiving. I thought I'd be clever and sneak a piece, when you just come in here and catch me.
Well if it makes you feel any better, she probably counted all the pieces before she went to bed. She'll wake up, check on it.

[looks scared]
Y'think?
Yup.

[Bob is cutting the turkey]
Listen, Bob, if you hold that knife right here, then you get a better-
[attempts to guide Bob's hand, and the knife cuts Bob's hand]
Oh, oh, I'm sorry there, Bobby!

[mutters to himself]
Why don't you carve the goddamn turkey yourself, you old fart!

[is surprised]
Uh, what's that?

[looks Howe squarely in the eye]
I said why don't you carve the goddamn turkey yourself, you old fart!
What the hell are you trying to do?
Nothing.
[walks away]

[calls after him]
What is the matter with you?
You are what's the matter with me!

[narration]
The history of my family, like the history of civilization, is the history of war. The getting into it, and outta it, and over it... and Vietnam should have been no different. But it was. It's final battle was fought on an unrecognized front, far from the shellings and the napalm and the guns and the shooting... it was a battle my brother Jeremy fought when he came back.
I always say, you give me forty-five minutes and a Bible and I can prove conclusively that Noah's Ark could not have been in Turkey!
Oh, he can.
I should study my Bible more.
Well, it had to be somewhere, now, I don't know where exactly, well, I'm not up on it like I should be. But somewhere in the Alps.
